head.title: Non-perturbative scaling in the scalar theory

article.h1: Non-perturbative scaling in the scalar theory

span.span:
Osservatorio Astrofisico, UniversitÃ di Catania
Viale Andrea Doria 6, 95125 Catania, Italy
INFN, sezione di Catania
Corso Italia 57, 95128 Catania, Italy

div.p: A new approach to study the scaling behavior of the scalar theory near the Gaussian fixed point in dğ‘‘italic-dd-dimensions is presented. For a class of initial data an explicit use of the Greenâ€™s function of the evolution equation is made. It is thus discussed under which conditions non-polynomial relevant interactions can be generated by the renormalization group flow.

Recent studies have discussed the possibility that at the Gaussian Fixed Point (GFP) of the Oâ¢(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘italic-O OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:)O(N) invariant scalar theory new relevant eigen-directions exist. In particular in [1] Halpern and Huang have found a class of non-polynomial relevant interactions at the GFP by means of Wilsonâ€™s renormalization group (RG) transformation with the â€œsharpâ€ momentum shell integration, but their result is still much debated [2, 3].

In fact an interesting question to study is the general features of the scaling around the GFP. In particular it would be important to have a global understanding of all the possible solutions in order to discuss the structure of the continuum limit.

A necessary condition to describe this limit is to select a set of marginal and relevant scaling eigen-operators at this fixed point. A scaling eigen-operator is a solution of the linearised fixed point equation of the form

semantics.annotation: italic-u RELOP:equals OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Lambda ARG:end ARG:start italic-k ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)
u=\left({\Lambda\over k}\right)^{\nu}h(x)

div.p: where xğ‘¥italic-xx is the dimensionless field, Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda is the UV overall cut-off, kğ‘˜italic-kk is the running cut-off and Î½ğœˆitalic-nu\nu is a scaling exponent. While in perturbation theory only a finite number of polynomial relevant and marginal interactions are considered, it is still not clear if new non-perturbative non-polynomial relevant scaling interactions can be generated by the RG flow. Were this true, it would mean for instance that the polynomial interactions cannot span all the continuum physics.

The aim of this work is to clarify some aspects of this question. Instead of using the methods discussed in [1, 5, 6], the Greenâ€™s function of the linearised renormalization group equation is constructed. It will be thus shown the role played by the boundary conditions in determining the structure of the scaling fields and it will be shown that is possible to generate relevant non-polynomial interactions not belonging to the same universality class of the polynomial interactions.

The most convenient way to address such a question is to use the Wilsonian formulation of the RG transformation. In particular we consider the local potential approximation (LPA) of Wegner-Houghton [4] equation as discussed in [5] for the N=1ğ‘1italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1N=1 components scalar theory, but we shall not restrict the potential to a polynomial.
The flow equation for the scaling field uâ¢(x,t)ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)u(x,t) reads [5, 6]

math.alttext: {\partial u\over\partial t}=d\;u-{d-2\over 2}\;x\;{\partial u\over\partial x}+% a_{d}\;{\partial^{2}u\over\partial x^{2}}

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-u ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-t ARG:end RELOP:equals italic-d italic-u ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-x FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-u ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-x ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-u ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end
{\partial u\over\partial t}=d\;u-{d-2\over 2}\;x\;{\partial u\over\partial x}+% a_{d}\;{\partial^{2}u\over\partial x^{2}}

div.p: where d>2ğ‘‘2italic-d RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2d>2 is the dimension of the spacetime, Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda is the UV cut-off, ad=1/(2â¢Ï€)dâ¢Î“â¢(d/2)subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘1superscript2ğœ‹ğ‘‘Î“ğ‘‘2italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-square-root ARG:start italic-pi ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Gamma OPEN:( italic-d MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)a_{d}=1/({2\sqrt{\pi}})^{d}\Gamma(d/2), and tâ‰¡lnâ¢Î›/kğ‘¡lnÎ›ğ‘˜italic-t RELOP:equivalent-to ln Lambda MULOP:divide italic-kt\equiv{\rm ln}\;{\Lambda/k}. The GFP is at uâ‰¡0ğ‘¢0italic-u RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:0u\equiv 0. In studying the UV region near the GFP one is interested in finding the unique function uâ¢(x,t)ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)u(x,t) which is continuous in the closed upper half plane -âˆ<x<âˆğ‘¥ADDOP:minus ID:infinity RELOP:less-than italic-x RELOP:less-than ID:infinity-\infty<x<\infty, 0â‰¤t0ğ‘¡NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-t0\leq t and satisfies eq.(2) with initial condition uâ¢(x,0)=fâ¢(x)ğ‘¢ğ‘¥0ğ‘“ğ‘¥italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)u(x,0)=f(x), -âˆ<x<âˆğ‘¥ADDOP:minus ID:infinity RELOP:less-than italic-x RELOP:less-than ID:infinity-\infty<x<\infty with fâ¢(x)âˆˆC0ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğ¶0italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:element-of italic-C POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf(x)\in C^{0}. We shall leave open the possibility that fğ‘“italic-ff is not bounded since there are no physical reasons to assume |uâ¢(Â±âˆ,t)|<âˆğ‘¢plus-or-minusğ‘¡VERTBAR:| italic-u OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus ID:infinity PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than ID:infinity|u(\pm\infty,t)|<\infty in discussing the scaling interactions.
It is convenient to make the transformation

semantics.annotation: italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-v OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:3 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-t MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: which brings (2), in the equivalent Fokker-Planck form [7]

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-v ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-t ARG:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( italic-v ADDOP:plus italic-x FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-v ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-x ARG:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
{\partial v\over\partial t}=-{d-2\over 2}\;(v+x\;{\partial v\over\partial x})+% a_{d}\;v_{xx}\\

div.p: After the rescaling xâ†’xâ¢(d-2)/2â¢adâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‘22subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘italic-x ARROW:rightarrow italic-x italic-square-root ARG:start OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:endx\rightarrow x\;\sqrt{(d-2)/2a_{d}}\; and tâ†’tâ¢(d-2)/2â‰¡Ï„â†’ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘‘22ğœitalic-t ARROW:rightarrow italic-t OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 RELOP:equivalent-to italic-taut\rightarrow t\;(d-2)/2\equiv\tau, it reads

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-v ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-tau ARG:end RELOP:equals italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ italic-v CLOSE:] PUNCT:, italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-x ARG:end OPEN:[ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-x ARG:end ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:]
\displaystyle{\partial v\over\partial\tau}=L_{\rm FP}[v],\hskip 56.905512ptL_{% \rm FP}\equiv{\partial\over\partial x}\left[{\partial\over\partial x}-x\right]

div.p: where we have introduced the Fokker-Planck operator LFPsubscriptğ¿FPitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP}. It is not difficult to build a Greenâ€™s function for such an operator. Let us define the formally self-adjont operator

semantics.annotation: italic-L RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus OPEN:[ ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:] RELOP:equivalent-to ADDOP:minus italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ho POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end
L=e^{-{x^{2}/4}}L_{\rm FP}e^{{x^{2}/4}}=-\left[-{\partial^{2}\over\partial x^{% 2}}+{x^{2}\over 4}+{1\over 2}\right]\equiv-H_{\rm ho}-{1\over 2}

div.p: being Hhosubscriptğ»hoitalic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ho POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{\rm ho} the Hamiltonian of the quantum mechanical harmonic oscillator with â„=Ï‰=1Planck-constant-over-2-piğœ”1ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi RELOP:equals italic-omega RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\hbar=\omega=1 and mass m=1/2ğ‘š12italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2m=1/2. We shall refer to the description in terms of such an operator and eigenfunctions as the quantum-mechanical (QM) frame, as opposed to the Fokker-Planck (FP) frame in eq.(5). The eigenfunctions of Lğ¿italic-LL have the asymptotic behavior âˆ¼eÂ±x2/4similar-toabsentsuperscriptğ‘’plus-or-minussuperscriptğ‘¥24RELOP:similar-to italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim e^{\pm x^{2}/4} as |x|â†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¥VERTBAR:| italic-x VERTBAR:| ARROW:rightarrow ID:infinity|x|\rightarrow\infty. For Lğ¿italic-LL to be self-adjoint only the damped exponential must be chosen, and the eigenfunctions are know from Quantum Mechanics. In particular the spectrum of Lğ¿italic-LL satisfies Lâ¢Ï†n=-(n+1)â¢Ï†nğ¿subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›1subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›italic-L italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL\;\varphi_{n}=-(n+1)\varphi_{n} with n=0,1,2,â‹¯ğ‘›012â‹¯italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ID:cdotsn=0,1,2,\cdots and all the eigenvalues of Lğ¿italic-LL are eigenvalues of LFPsubscriptğ¿FPitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP} with eigenfunctions LFPâ¢Ï•n=-(n+1)â¢Ï•n=ex2/4â¢Ï†nsubscriptğ¿FPsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›ğ‘›1subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¥24subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP}\phi_{n}=-(n+1)\phi_{n}=e^{x^{2}/4}\varphi_{n} Therefore a complete and orthonormal set of eigenfunctions for the LFPsubscriptğ¿FPitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP} operator reads

semantics.annotation: italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-pi ARG:end italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTFIX:factorial ARG:end ARG:end italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x MULOP:divide italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:)

div.p: where Hnsubscriptğ»ğ‘›italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{n} are the Hermite polynomials, with the orthonormality condition

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-x RELOP:equals italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
\langle\phi_{n}|\phi_{m}\rangle=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}e^{-x^{2}/2}\;\phi_{n}% \phi_{m}\;dx\;=\;\delta_{mn}

div.p: Thus the linear space generated by the set Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\phi_{n} is â„’2â¢(â„›)superscriptâ„’2â„›caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-R CLOSE:){\cal L}^{2}({\cal R}) with the norm ||f||=âŸ¨f|fâŸ©normğ‘“inner-productğ‘“ğ‘“VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| italic-f VERTBAR:| VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start OPEN:langle italic-f VERTBAR:| italic-f CLOSE:rangle ARG:end||f||=\sqrt{\langle f|f\rangle}. It is now straightforward to write down the Greenâ€™s function Gâ¢(x,Ï„|y,0)ğºğ‘¥conditionalğœğ‘¦0italic-G OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau VERTBAR:| italic-y PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)G(x,\tau|y,0) of the Fokker-Planck operator from the well known expression of the Greenâ€™s function of the harmonic oscillator. We have

semantics.annotation: italic-G OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau VERTBAR:| italic-y PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-x VERTBAR:| italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-tau italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-y CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-tau OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:)
\displaystyle G(x,\tau|y,0)=\langle x|e^{\tau L_{\rm FP}}|y\rangle=e^{-{y^{2}/% 2}}\sum_{n}e^{-\tau(n+1)}\phi_{n}(x)\phi_{n}(y)

RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-tau OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:) italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
\displaystyle=e^{-{y^{2}/2}}e^{x^{2}/4}\sum_{n}e^{-\tau(n+1)}\varphi_{n}(x)% \varphi_{n}(y)e^{y^{2}/4}

RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:langle italic-x VERTBAR:| italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-tau OPEN:( italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ho POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-y CLOSE:rangle italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 ADDOP:minus italic-tau MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
\displaystyle=e^{x^{2}/4}\langle x|e^{-\tau(H_{\rm ho}+{1\over 2})}|y\rangle e% ^{-{y^{2}/4}-\tau/2}

RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-pi sinh italic-tau ARG:end ARG:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 sinh italic-tau ARG:end OPEN:( italic-x italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-y CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)
\displaystyle=\sqrt{{e^{-\tau}\over 4\pi\;{\rm sinh\tau}}}\exp\left(-{e^{\tau}% \over 4\;{\rm sinh\tau}}\;(x\;e^{-\tau}-y)^{2}\right)

div.p: This precisely what we find in [7] with a summation formula of the Hermite polynomials. Therefore the unique solution of (5) which is continuous and satisfies the following initial conditions vâ¢(x,0)=fâ¢(x)ğ‘£ğ‘¥0ğ‘“ğ‘¥italic-v OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)v(x,0)=f(x) with |âŸ¨Ï•n|fâŸ©|<âˆinner-productsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›ğ‘“VERTBAR:| OPEN:langle italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-f CLOSE:rangle VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than ID:infinity|\langle\phi_{n}|f\rangle|<\infty is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-v OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau CLOSE:) RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-G OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau PUNCT:; italic-y PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) italic-f OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:) italic-d italic-y
v(x,\tau)=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}G(x,\tau;y,0)f(y)\;dy

div.p: We now come to the main questions of our investigation, namely to study the subspace of relevant and marginal interactions present at the fixed point. It is not difficult to see that the solutions of eq.(2) that âˆˆL2â¢(R)absentsuperscriptnormal-L2normal-RRELOP:element-of caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-R CLOSE:)\in{\cal L}^{2}({\cal R}) which are not bounded as tâ†’+âˆnormal-â†’ğ‘¡italic-t ARROW:rightarrow ADDOP:plus ID:infinityt\rightarrow+\infty have nâ‰¤2â¢d/(d-2)ğ‘›2ğ‘‘ğ‘‘2italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:2 italic-d MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)n\leq 2d/(d-2) in the spectrum of LFPsubscriptğ¿normal-FPitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP}.

The proof is a consequence of the spectral properties of the flow evolution operator: given fâˆˆâ„’2â¢(â„›)ğ‘“superscriptâ„’2â„›italic-f RELOP:element-of caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-R CLOSE:)f\in{\cal L}^{2}({\cal R}) as an initial condition, from (3) and (13) one has

semantics.annotation: italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:3 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-t MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-G OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau VERTBAR:| italic-y PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) italic-f OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:)
\displaystyle u(x,t)=e^{(3d-2)t/2}\int^{+\infty}_{-\infty}G(x,\tau|y,0)f(y)

RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:3 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-t MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-tau OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:) italic-f OPEN:( italic-y CLOSE:) italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-y
\displaystyle=e^{(3d-2)t/2}\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\sum_{n}e^{-\tau(n+1)}\phi_% {n}(x)\phi_{n}(y)f(y)e^{-{y^{2}\over 2}}dy

RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-n MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) OPEN:langle italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-f CLOSE:rangle
\displaystyle=\sum_{n}e^{(d-{(d-2)n/2})t}\phi_{n}(x)\langle\phi_{n}|f\rangle

div.p: where we have used eq.(11) and the uniform convergence of the sum. From the last line we see that in order to have a solution that grows for t>0ğ‘¡0italic-t RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0t>0 it must be nâ‰¤2â¢d/(d-2)ğ‘›2ğ‘‘ğ‘‘2italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:2 italic-d MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)n\leq{2d/(d-2)}. If we set f=Ï•mğ‘“subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘šitalic-f RELOP:equals italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf=\phi_{m} we recover the subspace of marginal and relevant eigenvectors spanned by the first nâ‰¤2â¢d/(d-2)ğ‘›2ğ‘‘ğ‘‘2italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:2 italic-d MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)n\leq 2d/(d-2) Hermite polynomials, as it has already found in the previous literature [5, 6]. Non-polynomial interactions may be evolved by means of the Greenâ€™s function provided |âŸ¨Ï•n|fâŸ©|<âˆinner-productsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›ğ‘“VERTBAR:| OPEN:langle italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-f CLOSE:rangle VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than ID:infinity|\langle\phi_{n}|f\rangle|<\infty, but these will not be of the form (1) and therefore cannot be considered as scaling fields. More specifically if we try to evolve an initial datum that behaves like expâ¡(qâ¢x2)ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥2OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( italic-q italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\exp(qx^{2}) for xâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¥italic-x ARROW:rightarrow ID:infinityx\rightarrow\infty with q<1/2ğ‘12italic-q RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2q<1/2, we find uâ¢(x,t)âˆ¼e(3â¢d-2)â¢t/2â¢expâ¡(e-(d-2)â¢tâ¢qâ¢x2)similar-toğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’3ğ‘‘2ğ‘¡2superscriptğ‘’ğ‘‘2ğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥2italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:3 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-t MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)u(x,t)\sim e^{(3d-2)t/2}\exp(e^{-(d-2)t}qx^{2}) as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡italic-t ARROW:rightarrow ID:infinityt\rightarrow\infty (note that |âŸ¨Ï•n|fâŸ©|=âˆinner-productsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›ğ‘“VERTBAR:| OPEN:langle italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| italic-f CLOSE:rangle VERTBAR:| RELOP:equals ID:infinity|\langle\phi_{n}|f\rangle|=\infty if qâ‰¥1/2ğ‘12italic-q RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2q\geq 1/2. ).

We want now to show that the space where all the possible physically meaningful scaling interactions live is greater than â„’2â¢(â„›)superscriptâ„’2â„›caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-R CLOSE:){\cal L}^{2}({\cal R}). The key point to be noticed is that the QM frame does not reproduce all the possible solutions present in the FP frame. This is because Lğ¿italic-LL is self-adjoint for the boundary conditions at infinity of the type Ï†nâ†’e-x2/4â†’subscriptğœ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¥24italic-varphi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:rightarrow italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\varphi_{n}\rightarrow e^{-x^{2}/4}. In this case from Sturm-Liouville theory we know that the spectrum is bounded and the number of relevant and marginal interactions is thus finite [8]. However LFPsubscriptğ¿FPitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP} is not self-adjoint and its spectrum is greater than the self-adjoint extension of Lğ¿italic-LL. In fact, although there are no non-stationary solutions of the linearised equation in the QM frame, a non-trivial zero mode is present in the spectrum of the LFPsubscriptğ¿FPitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP} operator, namely

semantics.annotation: italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: which of course âˆ‰â„’2â¢(â„›)absentsuperscriptâ„’2â„›RELOP:not-element-of caligraphic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-R CLOSE:)\not\in{\cal L}^{2}({\cal R}) and it corresponds to the following non-stationary solution of the original equation (2)

semantics.annotation: italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:3 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-t MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: where we have inserted the factor (d-2)/2â¢adğ‘‘22subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘italic-square-root ARG:start OPEN:( italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end\sqrt{(d-2)/2a_{d}} in the definition of xğ‘¥italic-xx. This is a perfectly well defined and regular scaling field which is â€œrelevantâ€ because it grows in the IR, with scaling dimension Î½=(3â¢d-2)/2ğœˆ3ğ‘‘22italic-nu RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:3 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\nu=(3d-2)/2, and it does not belong to the subspace spanned by the Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\phi_{n} eigenfunctions previously constructed. It is therefore a non-perturbative scaling field (the connection of this solutions with the type discussed in [1] is not immediately clear to me although their asymptotic behavior for large xğ‘¥italic-xx is similar to what discussed in [1].). In Quantum Mechanics or in Ornstein-Uhlenbeck diffusion processes one would discard such a solution because of the boundary conditions at infinity. In our context there is no specific reason for not considering scaling fields of this type.

Given this particular zero mode of the LFPsubscriptğ¿FPitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{\rm FP} operator it is immediate to write down the general solution of the homogeneous equation LFPâ¢[v]=0subscriptğ¿FPdelimited-[]ğ‘£0italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start FP POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ italic-v CLOSE:] RELOP:equals NUMBER:0L_{\rm FP}[v]=0 which is of the form

semantics.annotation: italic-v OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-A ADDOP:plus italic-B erf OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-x ARG:end ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:)
v(x,\tau)=e^{x^{2}/2}\left(A+B\;{\rm erf}\;({x\over\sqrt{2}})\right)

div.p: being Ağ´italic-AA and Bğµitalic-BB two arbitrary constants of integration. More generally if we set vnâ¢(x,Ï„)=eÎ»â¢Ï„â¢hÎ»â¢(x)subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›ğ‘¥ğœsuperscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğœsubscriptâ„ğœ†ğ‘¥italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-lambda italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)v_{n}(x,\tau)=e^{\lambda\tau}h_{\lambda}(x) eq.(5) reads

semantics.annotation: italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-x italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-lambda ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-h OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0
h^{\prime\prime}(x)-xh^{\prime}(x)-(\lambda+1)h(x)=0

div.p: For integer and non-negative values of Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda a particular solution of the homogeneous equation (20) can always be found with the Laplace method. One explicitly finds for Î»=1,2,3,4ğœ†1234italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 PUNCT:, NUMBER:4\lambda=1,2,3,4

semantics.annotation: italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-x italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:3 italic-x ADDOP:plus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:3 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:6 italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

div.p: It should be stressed that solutions of the type (21) which are even function of xğ‘¥italic-xx are bounded from below and a linear combination may develop non-trivial minima at some value of the field. This is the case of h4â¢e4â¢Ï„+câ¢h2â¢e2â¢Ï„subscriptâ„4superscriptğ‘’4ğœğ‘subscriptâ„2superscriptğ‘’2ğœitalic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-c italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endh_{4}e^{4\tau}+c\;h_{2}e^{2\tau} for some negative values of the constant cğ‘italic-cc. The general solution is

semantics.annotation: italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-tau CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-A italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-B italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) INTOP:integral POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-s CLOSE:)
v_{n}(x,\tau)=e^{n\tau}\left(A\;h_{n}(x)+B\;h_{n}(x)\int^{x}e^{s^{2}/2}\;h_{n}% (s)^{-2}ds\right)

div.p: where hnsubscriptâ„ğ‘›italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{n} is obtained with the Laplace method and n=0,1,2,â‹¯ğ‘›012â‹¯italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ID:cdotsn=0,1,2,\cdots.

The presence of solutions of the flow equation with entirely different physical implications should not come as a surprise. In d=2ğ‘‘2italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:2d=2 eq.(2) admits the following solutions, as it can be checked by direct substitution,

semantics.annotation: italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 italic-pi CLOSE:) italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end TRIGFUNCTION:cosine OPEN:( italic-beta italic-x CLOSE:)
\displaystyle u(x,t)=e^{(2-\beta^{2}/4\pi)t}\cos(\beta x)

italic-u OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:2 ADDOP:plus italic-gamma MULOP:divide NUMBER:4 italic-pi CLOSE:) italic-t POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-square-root ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
\displaystyle u(x,t)=e^{(2+\gamma/4\pi)t}e^{\sqrt{\gamma}x}

div.p: where Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta and Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma are arbitrary constants. The first one describes the physics of the Sine-Gordon theory, while the second one defines the Liouville theory [9]. Also in this case the same fixed point may describe entirely different physical theories.

The physical relevance (if any) of these solutions is not clear to us. Although one may speculate about their possible applications to the Standard Model or to Cosmology, all we can say for the moment is that the structure of the GFP for a simple scalar theory is richer than previously discussed. In particular, the universality class spanned by the polynomial eigen-potentials in the LPA does not contain all the possible relevant interactions.

One final remark is the following. We have used the linearised Wegner-Hougton equation in the LPA approximation with sharp cut-off. This equation is the same of the Polchinski equation obtained with the smooth cut-off, apart for the unimportant constant adsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{d} [3]. Thus our result is quite robust since these new scaling scaling exponents does not depend on the cut-off function used in the derivation.
I am very much indebted with Martin Reuter and Dario ZappalÃ for very enlightening discussions and encouragements.

F. J. Wegner and A. Houghton, Phys. Rev A8, 401 (1972).
A. Hasenfratz and P. Hasenfratz, Nucl Phys. B270, 687 (1986).
A.Bonanno D. ZappalÃ¡, Phys.Rev.D56, 3759, (1997) and hep-th/9709155
H. Risken, The Fokker-Planck Equation, Springer-Verlag, 1989
M. Reuter and C. Wetterich, Nucl.Phys. B506, 483, (1997).
